articles.headline: An Angry Obama Renounces Ties to His Ex-Pastor
articles.snippet: A week before two key primaries, the controversy surrounding his ex-pastor again erupted into a threat to Barack Obama’s ability to unify the Democrats.
articles.abstract: A week before two key primaries, the controversy surrounding his ex-pastor again erupted into a threat to Barack Obama’s ability to unify the Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  Senator Barack Obama broke forcefully on Tuesday with his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., in an effort to curtail a drama of race, values, patriotism and betrayal that has enveloped his presidential candidacy at a critical juncture.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Some Chinese Exporters Prefer Euros to Dollars
articles.snippet: Facing losses tied to a falling dollar and weakening American demand, some Chinese exporters are asking European customers to pay in euros. Others are trying to increase domestic sales.
articles.abstract: Facing losses tied to a falling dollar and weakening American demand, some Chinese exporters are asking European customers to pay in euros. Others are trying to increase domestic sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  Facing the double-barreled threat of a falling dollar and weakening American demand, some Chinese exporters are starting to ask European customers to pay in euros.

articles.headline: Easing the Pain at Airports
articles.snippet: While airlines have cut back even on normal services, some airports are trying to make life easier for travelers.
articles.abstract: While airlines have cut back even on normal services, some airports are trying to make life easier for travelers.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAREN W. ELLIS, customer services manager at the airport in Atlanta, is used to getting a certain reaction when she describes her job.
articles.byline: By Joe Sharkey and Hilary Howard

articles.headline: The Road to a Jumbo Mortgage Was Supposed to Get Easier
articles.snippet: The effort to make it easier to get loans over $417,000 has yielded frustration, with many saying the loans are not available or the rates are far higher than they expected.
articles.abstract: The effort to make it easier to get loans over $417,000 has yielded frustration, with many saying the loans are not available or the rates are far higher than they expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early February, Congress gave beleaguered mortgage borrowers a rare cause for celebration. As part of the economic stimulus package, it passed rules intended to make it easier and less expensive for people to take out hefty loans in the nation’s costliest housing markets.

articles.headline: A New Wave of Vilifying Short Sellers
articles.snippet: Short sellers are drawing fire once again, being accused of spreading rumors, persecuting companies and unsettling entire economies.
articles.abstract: Short sellers are drawing fire once again, being accused of spreading rumors, persecuting companies and unsettling entire economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days when square-rigged galleons plied the spice route to the East, the Dutch outlawed a band of rebels that they feared might plunder their new-found riches.

articles.headline: Federal Money in Health Care Plan From McCain
articles.snippet: The senator called for the federal government to give money to states to help cover people who have been denied health insurance.
articles.abstract: The senator called for the federal government to give money to states to help cover people who have been denied health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.  Senator John McCain detailed his plan to solve the nation’s health care crisis in a speech here Tuesday, calling for the federal government to give some money to states to help them cover people with illnesses who have been denied health insurance.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Kevin Sack

articles.headline: Federal Mortgage Plan Falls Short, Critics Say
articles.snippet: Statistics show that most people who have refinanced are homeowners who make their payments on time, not borrowers in crisis.
articles.abstract: Statistics show that most people who have refinanced are homeowners who make their payments on time, not borrowers in crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fewer than 2,000 homeowners at risk of foreclosure have been helped by a Federal Housing Administration program that President Bush promised would help homeowners who had fallen behind on their mortgage payments, federal housing statistics show.

articles.headline: Against Odds, New Orleans Schools Fight Back
articles.snippet: There is still disorder in many classrooms in New Orleans, but there is also learning going on, amid the struggle.
articles.abstract: There is still disorder in many classrooms in New Orleans, but there is also learning going on, amid the struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  No road leads to George Washington Carver Senior High School here. It sits on no street and has no address. No sign announces it.

articles.headline: Shortages Threaten Farmers’ Key Tool: Fertilizer
articles.snippet: Shrinking grain stocks and an increasing appetite for meat have collided with a shortage of fertilizer.
articles.abstract: Shrinking grain stocks and an increasing appetite for meat have collided with a shortage of fertilizer.
articles.lead_paragraph: XUAN CANH, Vietnam  Truong Thi Nha stands just four and a half feet tall. Her three grown children tower over her, just as many young people in this village outside Hanoi dwarf their parents.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Patent Law Battle a Boon to Lobbyists
articles.snippet: In 15 months, two dueling business coalitions have spent $4.3 million lobbying on legislation that calls for the biggest changes in United States patent law in more than 50 years.
articles.abstract: In 15 months, two dueling business coalitions have spent $4.3 million lobbying on legislation that calls for the biggest changes in United States patent law in more than 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A fight has erupted in Congress over the question of whether drug makers and other companies should be allowed to keep patents they obtained by misrepresentation or cheating.
